segments.text: Were there ever any Aggie pranks in your classes in those early years?
Any good bull stuff?
Let's see.
I remember as a high school teacher, a hamburger cheese being put on the doorknob.
No, I can't.
I think the students were just incredibly good.
Describe your workload and the courses that you started off teaching.
I remember developing a course on the foundations of education, and I think I taught three courses.
Foundations of Education, the History and Philosophy of Education, and I can't remember.
All right, these were for undergraduates.
These were all undergraduate classes.
Normally what year?
Well, supposedly the junior year.
I think education courses prior to the third year did not count.
So they were mainly junior and seniors.
And I think I had several sections, maybe
When I talk about three classes, I'm talking about two sections of one of these.
But in my first few years, I taught a number of—developed a lot of different courses, including comparative, and then started developing graduate-level courses in history and philosophy.
About how many per section in those years?
The class room I had was not air-conditioned.
It was up on the fourth floor, and I think it held about ninety.
I usually had a pretty full class, and that would be a couple sections.
We also taught two courses each summer session, so the summer sessions were
really murderous because everything was condensed.
I always believed in essays and papers.
I was very busy, especially in the summer, to get everything graded.
In those long semester classes, you normally gave how many tests and what other assignments?
I always would have pretty much daily reading, and I would have occasional quizzes pop and other when announced.
And then I would have, I think generally I would write about three major tests in the final.
which I soon learned seniors didn't have to take.
Graduating seniors.
Graduating seniors.
And then I would have a major paper.
And you didn't have a graduate assistant in those years?
No.
Well, I did at one time have a graduate assistant,
I asked not to have one in there because he took too much of my time talking.
I enjoyed talking to him, and I liked to see the papers myself, but he did help with attendance and things like that.
It was helpful, but he took more of my time than I think he saved, so I didn't need it.
But I could have had help.
And your classes, normally the classrooms were in the academic building.
Yes, and then occasionally I had a class in that little annex where the library, not the library but the
Harrington Annex is the two floor building.
They had a little shack kind of a building there.
At that time, what was your evaluation of the library holdings in the areas of education?
I was pleasantly surprised.
Of course, I had come from a small liberal arts college where education was not at all respected.
And the library here was much, much better.
And they were very helpful in ordering books.
And of course, they had journals, the major journals that I needed.
And I was pleased with the library.
Of course, the library was making great strides at that time.
Did you get any impression of the status that education had on this campus?
Well, I thought it was held in high regard, which surprised me.
I think Dean Hubert probably helped
create that feeling.
One of my first articles for publication was on the history of the lower class status of education in higher ed.
I compared it to the lower class status of the minorities.
went back to the days in the ancient world where if you lived a bad life, you came back in the next life as a teacher or a fishmonger.
Now, he would be the dean of education for about seven or eight years.
Yes.
Describe him as you and your colleagues saw him as dean.
He was always hovering.
The hovering is important because you always wanted to be on your toes in case he showed up, and you wanted to be in your office, and you wanted to be busy.
He was
very conscientious, and you never knew if he was angry or not.
And when I worked with him on some lecture
things.
He would ask questions like, how many people do you expect at this session?
And I had no way of knowing, but he expected an answer.
He expected you to know everything, which I think was a good mode of operation because you always were prepared.
He was a very strong dean.
I think he said General Patton was his model.
Make believe that I did not know him.
Describe him physically.
He's very tall and lean, very handsome, strong features.
He's slightly bent forward as he walked, and he
engaged you very seriously at all times.
He was a very serious man, but I think, of course, he also had a sense of humor, but that was not displayed ordinarily.
What kind of hours did he keep working?
I think he was there all the time.
Was there a key secretary in the dean's office?
Oh, yes, Peggy.
Ritchie.
Ritchie, yes, Peggy.
She was just wonderful.
And also Brian Cole was assisting Dean Hubert.
In fact, I had him as a student in one of the undergraduate classes when he was applying to be certified to teach.
And he was outstanding from the very beginning.
Was McCandless in the dean's office yet?
Yes, McCandless was there.
I had one of his daughters in class.
Yes, and he was a very fine man.
What was his part of the leadership?
What was his task?
Frankly, I don't remember.
I don't remember his title, but I do remember working with him when we wanted to get students to go abroad.
This was around the early 1980s.
He was our liaison with the regents or the directors in trying to get us to have study abroad programs in comparative education, which was partly my field.
And he helped us get that through, and I think outside of foreign languages, education was quite early in getting study abroad going.
As you began to understand the College of Education, were there any areas that we were not covering here that surprised you?
Or in reverse, were there some areas we were covering that were a little unusual?
In terms of the curriculum?
Well, the course,
I had been told that when I came there would be more Foundation people, but they never got any more.
So I had the whole program.
So I really never got off the ground the way I wanted to have, where we could have more in-depth.
You can't teach the history of the world in one semester, or at least the
to any degree of significance, so I would have to take certain periods and develop them.
But I never, never until near my retirement did we ever get any more people that were trained somewhat in the foundations.
But this is true all over the country.
The foundations were declining with the rise of more competency-based education.
They didn't know just what the foundations were doing.
And my vision, of course, is that they were to create the liberal art dimension of the teacher.
Were there any areas that we included that surprised you that many education programs were not?
Well, this is the beginning of behavioral objectives.
Behaviorism was beginning to take over education.
This was not just here, but I think they were going
stronger here than where I had been previously.
Of course, behavioral objectives stressed the kinds of learning that could be observed and not the kind of learning that raised questions and provoked thought.
and I was never on that side of this movement, many courses were developed that you had to list the objectives to be obtained.
Of course, I sometimes think the most important objectives are ones we're not sure of when we start.
However, I must say that behavioral objectives did tend to lead us toward
the road where we wanted to go and made us stick to it.
As you began to settle in to this institution, describe your reaction to Aggie traditions.
Well, of course, the bonfire was the most burning tradition.
Did you and your family attend?
Oh, yes.
I brought the family.
My youngest son was on my shoulders.
He's the only one that could see.
We just enjoyed it.
Of course, all along the campus, each cadet would say,
And as some people said, they got houtied to death walking across campus, but it was so friendly and so spirited.
And I would always check on the freshmen that were coming in each year, and I would overhear their
work that they were doing and watched them polish Sully.
And it struck me that this is unique, this university, and it's more than just a community of students.
It is a community.
Did you ever go to Silver Taps early?
Yes.
I never went to Midnight Yale.
I never did that.
I must admit, I'm waiting until I can stay up that late.
What about, did you go to Muster early, in the early years?
Oh, yes, Aggie Muster.
It was my mother's birthday, by the way, April 21st, and I believe the first Muster was the year of her birth, 1903.
I've read that somewhere.
Of course, it goes back to San Jacinto, but I think the tradition.
My mother loved it, too.
She always wanted to go.
I think the muster was probably the most significant part of the tradition.
Now, how did you and the family become part of the community?
Describe settling in.
Well, I think the
My department head, as I say, invited us over.
Many of the faculty exchanged dinners.
We went to the First Presbyterian Church, and they were very, very friendly in getting us established and getting acquainted.
And of course, there were faculty meetings and the yearly president reception.
But we were starting to get to be too big to be a family, I think.
I don't recall any problems adjusting to the community.
What about the school system?
The school system, the children just took right to that.
I had some problems with the way they were teaching, but I never said anything.
What was your evaluation of the comparative quality of this school system and the one that you left in Pennsylvania?
I would say that they were
About the same.
The one we left in Pennsylvania was nothing to brag about.
We had been in New Jersey prior to that, and I think, although my oldest daughter had just started school, I think they had a little better facilities there.
But I was always quite pleased, and the children were happy in school.
I think the teachers were very conscientious.
My only feeling was there's more memory in reading the textbook and reciting it.
But that was true everywhere, I think.
Where did you all do your shopping?
Well, there was Piggly Wiggly, I remember, and Orr's bought them out, and my children called it Piggly Orr Wiggly.
And then I think there was another one down there where the Taste of China is.
There was a little grocery store where the Thruway town, the bypass is.
I think there was a Kroger's downtown.
The Townshire Shopping Center?
Yes.
The Townshire was just developed, I think, but there was another one on the—or Brown Shoe— At Villa Maria, that one— That one was—isn't that the Townshire?
No, Townshire was the one on down Texas going north.
Oh yeah, yes, that was there.
I was thinking of that one on Briarcrest.
I think it's Briarcrest.
Or Villa Maria, whatever.
In those early years, what did you and your family do for relaxation?
Well, I worked all the time, and I think this is why I lost my family.
But we did take trips.
We went to Big Bend, one of the first, I think it was spring vacation.
We loved that.
And we went to Galveston and Six Flags.
My family went back to New Jersey in the summers when I worked so hard.
My mother-in-law was a widow, and she had a little weekend farm, and they enjoyed that.
So they went for a few weeks every summer.
We generally traveled, but I couldn't take vacation when the students, when classes were going.
Then between classes was my big time for research.
And then, of course, I had two classes each, summer sessions.
So it was not easy to get away.
But there were so many things to do around town, and the children were involved in many activities with the school.
We played tennis.
How easy was it to become a Texan?
Well, I fell right in, but I think my wife, it took her a while.
She was used to the New York scene.
But I just took to it right away, and I loved the warm weather.
Having grown up in Chicago, I had enough of that ice and snow.
I couldn't believe that people lived here before air conditioning.
I got used to air conditioning right away.
Of course, I was worried about the expense, and I was going to issue tickets to the children so they couldn't go in and out so often.
But it was comfortable.
This is a note to the typist.

You don't need to include this in the typed version, but I remember a lady calling in a call-in show on KTRH in Houston many years ago, and the emcee's name was Alvin Van Black, and this lady said, Alvin, how did y'all live in Houston before air conditioning?
And he gave her a two-word answer, more slowly.
But what I remember as a graduate student at Rice, the landlady from whom I rented a room did most of her housework before 10 in the morning.
Then she closed the blinds, closed the shades, closed the curtains, and she did sedentary things.
She didn't cook any lunch.
She ate something out of the refrigerator that was cool.
And so her theory was she was keeping the cool air in the house.
And then at about six o'clock,
in the real hot months, then she opened everything up and then she went out and did things in the yard and she went shopping and so forth.
But that was her answer.
That's the way to do it.
We can adjust anything, I believe.
But I found the warm weather very, very nice.
All right, now you mentioned research.
What were you researching in the 70s?
In the 70s, I was mainly working on the history of the lower class to see how lower class people were educated.
And when I moved into the education of children, I mean the history of children,
which we know it's a little about.
There are very few documents on that.
We tell about our childhood, but we look at it through different eyes when we're adults.
Then that became one of my major concerns.
Then I developed a biography, starting with Frances Parker.
I did a biography of Senator Yarborough
Where did you find the materials for those research efforts?
Well, except for the Parker, I didn't have the full-life research.
But for Yarborough, I managed to visit him and his wife in Austin.
And then, of course, a lot of this was in the congressional records and so on.
Those were easily accessible presidential papers.
This is Senator Ralph Yarbrough, who was for many years an active leader of what was then considered
liberal wing of the Democratic Party in Texas.
Yes, and he apparently, of course, in addition to getting the Bilingual Act through, he told me in the secret session, or the closed session, his vote got the Civil Rights Bill through.
The history of childhood was just developing with Array's work on the centuries of childhood, and sources there are hard to come by.
We don't have a lot of diaries of children and so on, so much of my material had to be secondary.
And you published this where?
Well, there were several journals that I worked with.
One, the Educational Studies was the major vehicle of the American Association of Educational Studies, and I also published in Progressive Education, which died out about this time.
Oh.
The Forum.
My mind is going up.
Educational Thought, Philosophy of Education Journal.
I was the founder of the International Society for Educational Biography, first president in 1982.
That's still, and that journal was called Vitae Scholastae.
What was your most, of your early publications, of which one were you most proud?
Which was the most important of your early?
Well, I think my work with Francis Parker.
And then I did an additional work on his wife, who was a feminist, early feminist, called The Colonel's Lady.
Then I got very much interested in qualitative research.
I think my inside lives, the qualitative dimension of education, was probably my most important work, which was published in a book called Qualitative Education.
In those early years, how were individual faculty members
in education, how were they evaluated?
How did you know whether you were proceeding well or not?
Well, I believe from the very beginning we had student evaluation forms.
And we would discuss the results of these with the department head.
It was rather very informal.
Of course, later on it became more technical with the documentation and so on.
This was mainly just going over our student evaluations.
And I got some cute evaluations.
I remember one student, if only they'd give Dr. Campbell something good to teach.
Too much history.
But the students were always very, very kind.
But I think that's the only way we were evaluated.
And of course, going up for promotion was another matter.
Now you came with what rank?
I came as an associate professor, I think, and head of the department at Lycoming, and three years later I was eligible for tenure, and I think then I made professor.
But I came as an associate.
salaries and promotions on a merit basis as far as you would know?
They were not merit as far as I knew.
Here?
No, I don't remember.
They may have been, and of course the department head was the one who decided.
I was never much interested in salaries and what was going on.
I just wanted to do the best I could.
I'm sure there was some merit, but later on I think it was formally.
I don't like to think of merit.
I believe teachers should not be competing with one another.
describe the program when you got here.
Was there a master's degree already approved when you arrived?
I believe there was.
I believe that we had a master's, but I was not teaching at graduate level for several years.
It may have just been approved.
We were approved of our certification in various fields, and we were still developing elementary and secondary program, continually revising curriculum.
Our faculty meetings were always just continually revising.
It was a very pioneer kind of time.
I can't recall now about the master's, but it was several years before I developed graduate courses.
And then they cut all the foundations of the undergraduate, which I didn't think was a good idea.
So then I just was at the graduate level.
What were some marks of the progress that the College of Education was making?
As I say, we were developing the behavioral objective almost to the extent that courses were series of behaviors.
I think the College of Education was very avant garde.
In the beginning, we were not even known in the state of Texas.
They didn't know that Texas A&M had a College of Education.
I think we were still getting developed.
I was also the advisor for the Texas Education Society, and many of these students did not know.
When they went to conferences, they were not known.
But the college soon
became very visible in the state and was producing more and more students.
I'm sorry that I don't have the figures.
I'm sure they're officially documented somewhere.
Which other schools in Texas do you think were the most highly regarded in education?
Well, of course, the University of Texas.
I had a couple of Columbia friends who taught in the College of Education there in Austin.
I don't think there was, in foundations, there was nothing to compare.
And of course, they were much farther ahead than we were.
They had four or five foundation people.
I did attend some meetings down at the University of Houston, and they were going wild on this school without walls, which developed all over Houston.
And one time I taught an off-campus course in one of those buildings where there's no walls.
You have to just give people worksheets.
I mean, there's no way you can talk if you have a loud voice next door.
But they were kind of avant-garde in that.
Of course, Rice was not known for his education, but that of course was the
the elite school of Texas.
But I think in my field it was definitely the University of Texas.
Now Sherman had a good—I knew people at Sherman in foundations.
That was now the University of North Texas, I think.
You mean Denton?
Denton.
I'm sorry.
I'm so sorry.
Correct me, my faulty memory, it was in Denton.
Sherman is where Martha went to college, Austin College.
Yeah, and yours truly is in Austin College.
Did you go to Austin College?
I'd forgotten that.
She loved it there and I thought it was marvelous.
Oh, it was great for me.
They had a five-year education program.
My great honor came two falls ago.
I was the 150th anniversary sesquicentennial speaker.
Oh, for goodness sakes.
Well, you know, that is one of the oldest schools, and I think it was originally somewhere in Huntsville, wasn't it?
That's right.
They moved it up to Sherman because of malaria and yellow fever.
And they had an opera house, and it was bigger than Dallas, wasn't it?
Yes.
I recall picking up little things.
Oh, yes.
The campus leadership, Jack Williams and John Calhoun,
What did you and your colleagues think of Jack Williams and John Calhoun as the president and the vice president?
Very highly, very highly.
And I was in several meetings with Calhoun when I was with TACT and other organizations and thought so highly of him.
But Williams was the, I think, the inspiration for everybody.
Describe their manner and their style.
Well, Williams was a very smooth lecturer, but he was also very available.
He would sometimes sit down in the cafeteria and talk to faculty.
I think you had the feeling that he was on your side and he was trying to develop high standards, working to make this a great university, but he was very friendly in style.
I think Calhoun was too.
Calhoun was a little more impure.
